reviewText: This -=- as it says on the back cover of the five disc set -=- is"INTENDED FOR THE ADULT COLLECTOR AND IS NOT SUITABLE FOR CHILDREN."With THAT said, this is what a film collector would term the completist-decline of the group.It is a MUST-have for a collector -- even if "Alfalfa" is almost six feet tall and "Spanky" is bursting out of his pants!To a collector, certainly no worse than getting the JOE BESSER third stooge short subjects; right?You would do better to pick up these 52 (1938-1944) theatrical shorts ONLY a-f-t-e-r you have already seen Part one,otherwise known as THE LITTLE RASCALS.The Little Rascals: The Complete Collection{$45 new}--- now, don't get a used one -- the updated NEW one isbetter;but NOT better than the copletely unedited, so-called CABIN FEVER out-of-print VHS/DVD versions from many years ago.I bought the above seven (7) disc set, and replaced the discs with the updated discs that were released SEPERATELY -- if you wanted theoriginal shorts with original title cards -- though a few shorts are still slightly edited... like WASHIE IRONIE which is missingthe spitting 'washie' scene.The 5 seperate replacement discs are:{$6}=The Little Rascals Vol 1{$7}=Little Rascals 2{$7}=The Little Rascals Vol 3{$7}=The Little Rascals Vol 4{$7}=The Little Rascals Vol 5{$7}=The Little Rascals Vol 6{$7}=Little Rascals 7The best, unedited set has ALWAYS been:The Little Rascals: Vol 1 - 12 Cabin Fever Box Set (6 discs)... but, at $400, you'd EXPECT perfection -- wouldn't you?The seven(7) individual DVDs are inexpensive alternatives to the entire 7 disc set -- of course missing the nice gateway-fold set andcollectors' booklet.Another way to get these 88 shorts isThe Little Rascals Collectors Edition - 88 Classic Uncut Episodesfrom a vendor that also -- reportedly -- sends a bonus disc [Abbott&Costello;] as a freebie "thank-you"!All 88 Little Rascals shorts for less than $30 on 6 DVDs. The customer photograph section showed one collectionwith 11 DVDs. I have both of them, and while the video quality is "second-generational" and not pristine as on theother collections -- CABIN FEVER is the best uncut quality[at a price] but, also, is not IN as-filmed order, either.

reviewText: I was glad to be able to add the last of the Our Gang comedies to my collection.  These made at MGM were at the last of the series and although the do not compare to those of the Hal Roach golden years, they are interesting because they are part of the series and a look at the times in the late 30's and early 40's.  They are a companion to the classic episodes as are the silent ones.I recomind it to any Our Gang/Little Rascals true fans.
Title: N/A

reviewText: First off-the-bat, these are all 52 remaining Our Gang films, from 1938-1944, NOT 1942 as the description above reads. These 10-minute short films are the worst in Our Gang's history but I'm giving this collection five stars...and I'll tell you why. During the last few shorts during the Hal Roach period, Our Gang films began their downslide, as Spanky & Alfalfa were older and getting hammier in their acting. Once Roach sold the rights to MGM, the series took a nosedive - but they still had some good moments. The best actor from 1938-1940 was Tommy Bond (Butch) who is a more polished, natural actor; also, Sid Kibrick (Woim) is great as Butch's sidekick, even though his dialogue is limited to lines like, "yeah, Butch." But Spanky and Alfalfa became the worst "Our Gang" actors the older they got; Darla has moments of lameness too, but not to the extreme of Spank & Alf. Buckwheat was OK but was worse in the Gang's final years, 1942-1944. Porky left early, followed by Butch, Alfalfa, Darla (who was just starting to beautifully blossom) and finally, Spanky. They were eventually replaced by Mickey, Froggy & Janet; these last years (1941-1944) are referred to as "The Froggy Years" as one would complain about the awfulness of the films - but it's unfair to Billy "Froggy" Laughlin, as he was actually the series' saving grace. His acting was not as bad as we all thought - he actually pulls off some very funny moments, but we have to suffer through the awful, preachy plotlines to get to 'em....you also get to hear Froggy's REAL voice in a few of these films.What else made these lame? Little things.1) No Pete The Pup...the remainder of dogs were these little yappy dogs that always get under your feet with names like "Whiskers" and "Rover" - not big, lovable lugs like all the Petes during the Roach years.2) New, lesser "Gang" members with names like "Fatty" (no fatter than Spanky) and "Happy" (who has one of the biggest sourpuss faces and is anything BUT happy).3) Waayyyyy too many episodes had the gang putting on a show for one reason or another. Yawn. (Runnin' outta ideas?)4) The opening/closing theme - a medley of "London Bridge Is Falling Down/Farmer In The Dell." If they had kept the original theme it really, really woulda helped.5) Too many episodes where we, the audience, are supposed to learn a lesson. At certain points, some adult - a judge or equivalent of - looks right into the camera and addresses the audience with lines like "if each parent would take more time to teach their kids, blah-blah-blah." Also, too many "moral" episodes where the kids themselves get too preachy, especially Spanky; he becomes the "goody-goody" of the gang, which makes my heart sink. Mickey (Robert Blake) comes a close second. The worst of the bunch? "Time Out For Lessons," where Alfalfa learns that he should balance time between his football playing and schoolwork; after telling the gang "we're not gonna practice until we've done our homework" and his dad tells him to balance play with work, Alfalfa leaves to play football with the rest of the gang and utters, "FROM NOW ON, WE TAKE TIME OUT FOR LESSONS!!!" In real life, he'd probably be kicked off the team.6) Terrible special effects. Scenes when gang members go flying through the air look amateurish with wires clearly visible.So, why do I give this collection 5 stars?1) This is the first, and possibly only time you'll have the chance to get this complete collection of the rest of the gang films.2) It's also important that you watch and learn how NOT to treat a beloved series; either step up the quality or bow out entirely. Filmmakers should watch the "Our Gang" films beginning with the Hal Roach sound films (1929-1937) and then observe how the series deteriorated with these MGM episodes. A great, great filmmaking lesson is to be learned here.3) For collectors of comedy films of this period, it's a vital collection.4) The quality - video & audio - is top-notch.5) It's very family-friendly - probably even more so than then the original Hal Roach films (still contain some racial humor but less than the Roach films).So, yes, even with all it's flaws - AND THERE ARE MANY - it's still important for serious collectors. Five stars? Most definitely.

reviewText: These naturally funny, adorable children are absolutely timeless.  If you own the Little Rascals Complete Collection (1929-1938) a Must-Have!, this is the follow-up collection you cannot be without. I find there is little difference between the two wonderful series.  But if you truly want a complete collection you must include the following: Little Rascals Silent Shorts Vols.1&2 (1922-28?) sold BY Amazon, and the crucial full-length feature General Spanky('36).I did find it difficult to view a complete listing online so here you go!Disc 1 (1938 - 1939)Little Ranger, TheParty FeverAladdin's LanternMen In FrightFootball RomeoPractical JokersAlfalfa's AuntTiny TroublesDuel PersonalitiesClown PrincesCousin WilburDisc 2 (1939 - 1940)Joy ScoutsDog DazeAuto AnticsCaptain Spanky's ShowboatDad For A DayTime Out For LessonsAlfalfa's DoubleBig Premiere, TheAll About HashNew Pupil, TheBubbling TroublesSpanky McFarlandDisc 3 (1940 - 1941)Good Bad BoysWaldo's Last StandGoin' Fishin'Kiddie KureFightin' FoolsBaby BluesYe Olde Minstrels1-2-3 Go!Robot WrecksHelping HandsCome Back Miss PippsDisc 4 (1941 - 1943)Wedding WorriesMelodies Old And NewGoing To PressDon't LieSurprised PartiesDoin' Their BitRover's Big ChanceMighty Lak A GoatUnexpected RichesBenjamin Franklin, Jr.Family TroublesDisc 5 (1943 - 1944)Calling All KidsFarm HandsElection DazeLittle Miss PinkertonThree Smart GuysRadio BugsDancing RomeoTale Of A Dog

reviewText: The fidelity is fine throughout, the episodes are uncut and six or seven are at least passable.The rest is pretty much the Our Gang apocalypse.I guess this period needed to be documented on DVD -- honestly, a more worthy effort would have been locating and restoring all 93 silents -- but I'm not sure I needed to experience it again. The overall effect is like attending a very long funeral with no one present to speak for the deceased. I can't even recommend it to history-minded viewers. No background booklet or on-disc extras are included. (A shame, as there's precious little info out there on the "Miniatures" series with which MGM seemed to flirt in the later going as a potential Our Gang rebranding or Home Front Commandos -- the short in production when the hammer finally came down.)Do not look for classics. The Hal Roach years were full of them, but here you'll have to take minor pleasures where you find them. In the odd throwbacks (in whole or in part) to the earlier era -- like Aladdin's Lantern, Clown Princes, Auto Antics, Goin' Fishin', Fightin' Fools and Going to Press. In Mighty Lak a Goat from 1942, which breaks the traditional Our Gang format (and features a tiny bit with Ava Gardner that was directed by then-husband Mickey Rooney). In appearances by former Spanky sidekick Scotty Beckett as Alfalfa's cousin Wilbur and by Clarence Wilson, who had served so effectively as the villainous Mr. Crutch in Shrimps for a Day back in 1934, as school board president Mr. Pratt. In episodes that you may not have seen. (We were certain we'd seen them all, only to discover repeatedly that we had not.) Or in the simple fact that, through the rest of '38 and on into '39, this was still outwardly Our Gang, with all the beloved characters from the Hal Roach years.But it's a short honeymoon. As you approach the middle of the second of the five discs, minor pleasures can no longer camouflage a steep drop-off in quality. Beside the Roach naturalism, the vast majority of the MGM shorts come across as downright formal -- not to say stilted. It was inevitable that there would be some changes when the series moved between studios, but the ones that occurred suggest MGM's directors and writers, lacking experience with the series, also lacked a basic understanding of what made the Roach shorts work so well. If they had possessed that understanding, they might not have made so free with the series's basic premises. MGM took the Gang out of its own little world -- a huge part of the essential charm of earlier incarnations -- and eventually placed it in a town called "Greenpoint" with a significant population of Responsible Adults. (You'll never find as many grown-ups in the Roach films as you will here.) It skimped on the DIY inventions and happy extremes and killed outright the unscripted moments. (While Roach had captured children being children, MGM filmed actors acting and often over-acting.) The episodes grew flatter, colder, more formulaic and conventional and, after a while, preachy. Suddenly, our sense of knowing and even vicariously participating in this world was largely gone. By the time you get to Alfalfa's Double, a character is actually referring to the kids as "Our Gang" and Alfalfa to Buckwheat as "the colored boy" -- can you imagine any of that happening in a Roach short? -- and by 1940, the episodes begin to end with the gang laughing riotously. An easy out.Alas, there was little at this stage that was particularly funny.I'm reluctant to spend too much time parsing the differences between bad and awful -- suffice to say that, from the spring of 1941 on, it's largely awful -- but it's worth touching on one contributing factor: the disappearance in '39 and '40 of cast members who had helped define the series' final Roach incarnation. This was in itself a natural process repeated many times during the Roach years, but it again tested MGM's feel for the series and the studio again failed: It didn't display Roach's intuition for drafting replacements or promoting background players. Or, rather, it mishandled the changeovers just as it mishandled the series. Mickey Gubitosi (Robert Blake) was added to the cast in 1939 -- subbing first for solemn Junior under sadly telling circumstances and then for Porky as well -- and was quickly bumped up to featured player with disastrous results in the whiny, schmaltzy Dad for a Day and All About Hash.With the further addition of Billy "Froggy" Laughlin and Janet Burston in 1940, most of the elements for the absolute bottom-of-the-barrel shorts of 1943 (the final three of which aired in '44) were in place. (In fairness, Laughlin might have made a decent background character a la Jonathan "Uh-huh" Collum, but that would have required recognition by the powers-that-be that his voice was best used as an occasional gimmick.)Suffice to say the later episodes have little drawing power. Granted, longtime standby Spanky held on through 1942 and Buckwheat to the bitter end -- and I do mean bitter: The show in this era was chock-a-block with racial stereotypes -- but by their departure the characters had become nearly unrecognizable. In the end, killing the series MGM had itself degraded was as much as act of mercy for fans as one of financial prudence for the studio.
